statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Tracy McGrady made a shot from just inside the 3-point line with 1.8 seconds left to lead the Orlando Magic to an 85-83 victory over the Detroit Pistons on Friday night.
article.headline: Foul-plagued McGrady strikes at finish
article.linkText: McGrady's only second-half basket beats Pistons
article.story:
AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP) -- Tracy McGrady got some help from his teammates. Then, he paid them back. McGrady made a shot from just inside the 3-point line with 1.8 seconds left to lead the Orlando Magic to an 85-83 victory over the Detroit Pistons on Friday night. McGrady, who scored 12 points, sat out for more than 15 minutes in the second half after picking up a fourth foul in the first minute of the third quarter. When he left the game, the Pistons led 49-42. When McGrady returned, the Magic were ahead 75-73. "It's definitely frustrating to be in foul trouble when you're the key guy on the team, but the guys did well off the bench," McGrady said. "Then I gave up the ball in the final minute, and I said to myself, 'These guys worked too hard for you to blow the game like this.' I had to make something happen." Mike Miller scored 18 points to lead the Magic, who stopped a two-game losing streak and prevented the Pistons from their first five-game winning streak in over two years. Andrew DeClercq had season highs with 12 points and eight rebounds on his 29th birthday. "We showed a trait that we didn't show the other night," Orlando coach Doc Rivers said. "When they made a run or something bad happened to our team, we didn't hang our heads. When Tracy went out of the game, you could see that our guys really wanted to try to do well. Our lead actually increased with Tracy off the floor. That's impressive." Stackhouse scored 18 points on 8-of-20 shooting for Detroit, and reserve Corliss Williamson scored 15. Ben Wallace added 18 rebounds and four blocks. The Pistons had several chances to keep their winning streak alive, but couldn't control the ball. "It came down to one thing, turnovers," Detroit coach Rick Carlisle said. "You can't win in this league when you give them 27 points on 24 turnovers. We held them to 37 percent (shooting) and that's usually enough for us to win, but not when you don't take care of the ball." The Magic took their first lead in nearly 17 minutes, with 1:07 left in the third quarter, and began the fourth with a 65-63 lead. The Pistons tied it 83-83 with 45.4 seconds left on Chucky Atkins' two free throws after stealing the ball from McGrady. Atkins stripped Miller of the ball with about 20 seconds left, but Miller raced down the court to pick up a ball Atkins had tipped away by Darrell Armstrong. "I thought the last minute and a half was just bad basketball," Rivers said. "Fortunately, they had the last turnover and we had the last shot." McGrady's shot came around a screen after a timeout with 13.1 seconds left. "(Rivers) asked me if I wanted the ball and I said, 'Yes,"' McGrady said. "I had to let everything in the past go and make something happen with that shot." Stackhouse had a chance to tie it, but hit the side of the backboard on an off-balance shot from the baseline as time expired. Detroit led 24-22 after a first quarter that saw the Pistons score seven unanswered, then allow 13 straight points, before going on a 10-0 run. The Pistons led at halftime, 47-39.

Game notes
Orlando's Horace Grant did not make the trip, and missed his second straight game with an intestinal virus. ... Stackhouse scored 10 points in the first 4:28, but didn't score again until the final minute of the third. ... Orlando's other scorers in double figures were Armstrong (12), Troy Hudson (11) and Pat Garrity (10).
